title: Students Barricaded in Cooper Union, Livestream Protest
content:
Students that have barricaded themselves inside Cooper Union's landmark Foundation Building on Cooper Square are livestreaming their protest of the college's plan to bolster its finances by charging tuition for graduate programs.

The students planned the action for a month before 11 of them barricaded themselves inside the Peter Cooper suite Monday at noon, said Casey Gollan, a 21-year-old senior. One student journalist from the New School is also with them.

"We have a lot of supplies up here," Gollan said. "We're not in a position where we feel like we need to leave until we have things addressed."

Several faculty members joined some students at a press conference Tuesday afternoon outside the building to say they supported the Cooper Union's mission statement, which says the college awards full scholarships to undergraduates. Tuition is valued at $38,550.

They have three demands, including the resignation of the college's new President Jamshed Bharucha. The students also want the college to reaffirm its commitment to free education and to give them a say in college governance.

A college spokeswoman said the president has held meetings with other students this morning, and a new "financially sustainable plan is critical to the institution's survival."

"The 11 art students who have locked themselves in the Peter Cooper Suite do not reflect the views of a student population of approximately 1,000 architects, artists and engineers," spokeswoman Jolene Travis said in an e-mailed statement.

Travis said the president and other college officials have held more than 80 meetings with students, faculty and staff members, and alumni.

Facing a mounting deficit, the college floated the idea in November 2011 of charging tuition but students and faculty members immediately fought back.

Instead, the school's trustees decided to expand its 60-student graduate program and charge tuition.

Gollan said students have been particularly unhappy with what they see as a lack of communication from the new president, who took over in July 2011.
